author: Staff Reporter
text:
Two days after a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) petition was filed that raised objection to Hotel Diggi Palace being used as the venue of the Jaipur Literature Festival (JLF), the Rajasthan High Court, on Wednesday, issued a notice to the State government giving it a week’s time to reply.

The PIL filed by a Rajasthan based RTI activist Sanjeev Gupta said about 35,000 people attended JLF each day.

However, the venue could accommodate only 2,000 people.

The PIL also cited “traffic jam” and “a possible stampede” as problems that could be addressed only by shifting the venue of JLF from Diggi Palace to a place that could accommodate the huge crowd.

Speaking to The Hindu , Dr. Gupta’s lawyer Ajay Jain said, “Since the festival was to begin on January 21, the court kept the matter pending and directed the State government to reply to the issues in the PIL.”

“The court on Wednesday also ordered that the security at the festival be properly maintained and security [and traffic] related concerns of the petitioner addressed,” Mr. Jain said.
title: HC issues notice to Rajasthan over JLF venue
